title: There is a bank levy due to child support for over 30,000 on my negative balance checking account. Will bankruptcy help?
question: My ex likes to throw everything in my face and makes it hard for me to see my kids or bond with them. He even turns them against me. I have court ordered visitation but insists i go to court for visitation. He is receiving public assistance. As am I. My driver's license has a hold making it impossible to get around or get a job without relying on him for rides which he changes his mind on constantly. I also have a bank levy for -30,000$ on an overdrawn old checking account...he is planning to ask the judge it not be removed because they were going to release the hold on my license...he's on assistance...so am i, and im trying to find a job...im currently attending community college to gain skills for a career to help me earn enough money to support myself and kids without public assistance and he has a problem with that too..
answers: Child support is not dischargeable, so filing a bankruptcy with your facts is unlikely to help your situation. I would suggest you talk to a family law attorney--a free or reduced fee clinic might help you obtain relief.

Basically, you have two choices when it comes to filing personal bankruptcy: Chapter 7 or Chapter 13. Chapter 13 is not a likely option because you have to show you have a steady income sufficient to result in presenting a "feasible" plan to the court. Chapter 7 is better suited to your situation, but there is an express presumption that you cannot discharge "Child/spousal support" debts.

As to the levy on a overdrawn bank account, obviously no money will be recovered. The sheriff will return the writ to the court after the bank reports it has no funds to pay over. Why does the DMV have a hold on your driver's license? Usually, driving w/o insurance, having an accident w/o insurance or a DUI conviction results in suspension of your license.
Ufortunatelyfor you, child support cannot be wiped out in bankruptcy.
